body: @hariharans29 this will also affect performance of real model (resnet50 e.g.), we need to set intra_num_threads to get the same performance as **numactl** , but this is unnecessary for onnxruntime==1.6.0

When you create the InferenceSession, please also pass in a SessionOption, and in the option please set intra_op_num_threads  to a correct value.  Like this:

```python
import onnxruntime as rt

sess_options = rt.SessionOptions()

sess_options.intra_op_num_threads = 2
sess_options.execution_mode = rt.ExecutionMode.ORT_SEQUENTIAL
sess_options.graph_optimization_level = rt.GraphOptimizationLevel.ORT_ENABLE_ALL
```
intra_op_num_threads should be the number of cores you want to use.
@snnn  this is wired because **numactl** should have higher priority. Could you share more details about cores binding, for example, how to bind to specific cores outside the program?

It could because of this code; https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/8d737f977056444a307f1b7f0bcd402fba62d790/onnxruntime/core/util/thread_utils.cc#L19

Onnx runtime doesn't know you are using numactl.
So how can I bind the program to specific cores? for example, I need multi instances, the first instance was running on core 0-3, the second was running on core 4-7, and so on...
and why numactl can control onnxruntime1.6.0 ? I think this is a significant change of 1.7.0, right?

When you have multiple session on the same machine, you should explicitly set sess_options.intra_op_num_threads to a good value. So that each session will only use a portion of the total CPUs. By default each of them tries to use all of the CPUs. 

If you set intra_op_num_threads, then onnxruntime won't bind itself to specific CPU cores. You can use numactl  to do the job.
the question remains here. I can't use numactl to control the cores bindings, and intra_op_num_threads will only set the session on several threads (4 cores) not specific 4 cores (core 0,1,2,3).

> the question remains here. I can't use numactl to control the cores bindings, and intra_op_num_threads will only set the session on several threads (4 cores) not specific 4 cores (core 0,1,2,3).

so,how do you set the session on specific 4 cores (core 0,1,2,3) now,I also meet this problem,thks
Ok, let me disable onnx runtime's thread affinity logic.

issue.title: Can't bind ONNXRT C++ Application to single core using numa with sequential executor mode using default CPU EP (MLAS)

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
The onnxruntime_perf_test c++ application has two different modes of execution - sequential executor mode (default) and the parallel executor mode. By default, the application tries to exercise all the cores of the machine in both modes. However, we wanted to see the performance using single core and we used numa to bind the application to single core. Our observation was the following:

**1. With Sequential executor mode** - Though we use numa to bind the application to 1 core, it doesn't work and it ends up working as default (where it uses all cores)

**2. With Parallel executor mode** - When we use numa to bind the application to 1 core, it works with this mode and the application runs on single core.

**Urgency**
Medium.

**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04):  **Ubuntu 20.04.3 LTS**
- ONNX Runtime installed from (source or binary): **source**
- ONNX Runtime version: **v1.10.0**
- Python version: **3.8.10**
- Visual Studio version (if applicable): NA
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source): **7.5.0**
- CUDA/cuDNN version: NA
- GPU model and memory: NA

**To Reproduce**
- **Describe steps/code to reproduce the behavior.**
Build default CPU EP (MLAS) with ONNXRT v1.10.0 release.

- **Attach the ONNX model to the issue (where applicable) to expedite investigation.**
Download the tiny_yolov2 opset8 ONNX model from here:
https://github.com/onnx/models/tree/master/vision/object_detection_segmentation/tiny-yolov2/model

**Expected behavior**
When the c++ applications is ran using sequential executor mode and if numa is used to bind it to single core, it should work as expected.

**Screenshots**

**MLAS -Sequential Executor mode:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29036417/150929496-2f476765-0e55-476c-b577-3935872f79b7.png)

**MLAS - Parallel Executor Mode:**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29036417/150929742-60deafb3-3921-4ec4-87fc-485b06cf8c47.png)

**Note:**
we used Intel's VTune profiler Tool to get these screenshots of the core usage stats. The machine we used has 16 cores.

**Machine configuration:**
CPU(s):                          32
On-line CPU(s) list:             0-31
Thread(s) per core:              2
Core(s) per socket:              16


**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here. If the issue is about a particular model, please share the model details as well to facilitate debugging.

**Note:** This issue is seen only with default CPU EP. However we didn't observe similar issue while using OpenVINO EP.
so, also attaching the commands for OpenVINO EP as well, if you would like to try this out as well.

**commands to reproduce the same:**

**case 1: sequential executor mode with all cores (default case)**

**OpenVINO EP:**
./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -v -e openvino model.onnx

**MLAS:**
./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -v -e cpu model.onnx

**case 2: sequential executor mode with single core using numa**

**OpenVINO EP:**
numactl -m 0 --physcpubind 0 ./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -v -e openvino model.onnx

**MLAS:**
numactl -m 0 --physcpubind 0 ./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -v -e cpu model.onnx

**case 3: Parallel executor mode with all cores**

**OpenVINO EP:**
./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -P -v -e openvino model.onnx

**MLAS:**
./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -P -v -e cpu model.onnx

**case 4: Parallel executor mode with single core using numa  (works)**

**OpenVINO EP:**
numactl -m 0 --physcpubind 0 ./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -P -v -e openvino model.onnx

**MLAS:**
numactl -m 0 --physcpubind 0 ./onnxruntime_perf_test  -r 1 -c 1 -P -v -e cpu model.onnx
